data.formBody: Before answering any declaration please ensure that you have read and understood published guidance relating to the question.  This is available on our website (relative link provided) and/or included in the guidance for the application for registration, restoration or return to practise.

questionGroups.title: Declaration of fitness to practise
questionGroups.body: Under the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974 (Exceptions) Order 1975 and the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974 (Exclusions and Exceptions) (Scotland) Order 2003, you are exempt from the provisions of Section 4(2) of the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974. Therefore you are not entitled to withhold information about convictions which for other purposes are spent under the provisions of the Act, and failure to disclose such convictions could result in disciplinary action.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.body: Has a determination ever been made against you by a regulatory body in the United Kingdom responsible under any enactment for the regulation of a health or social care profession to the effect that your fitness to practise as a member of a profession regulated by that body is impaired, or a determination by a regulatory body elsewhere to the same effect?

questions.title: Have you previously advised the GPhC or the RPSGB of this information?
Question 2
questions.body: Do you currently have any problems with your physical or mental health that may impair your ability to practise safely and effectively or which otherwise impairs your ability to carry out your duties in a safe and effective manner?

questions.title: Have you previously advised the GPhC or the RPSGB of this information?
Question 3
questions.body: Have you previously been convicted or cautioned for a criminal offence in the British Islands or elsewhere (which, if committed in England, Scotland or Wales would constitute a criminal offence) or have you previously agreed to be bound over to keep the peace by a Magistrates’ court in England or Wales?

questions.title: Have you previously advised the GPhC or the RPSGB of this information?
Question 4
questions.body: Have you previously agreed to pay a penalty under section 115A of the Social Security Administration Act 1992 (penalty as alternative to prosecution)?

questions.title: Have you previously advised the GPhC or the RPSGB of this information?
Question 5
questions.body: Are you currently under investigation by any regulatory body (other than the GPhC) or criminal enforcement authority (e.g. police or NHS Counter Fraud Service) in the British Islands or elsewhere?

questions.title: Have you previously advised the GPhC or the RPSGB of this information?
Question 6
questions.body: Have you previously accepted a conditional offer under section 302 of the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 (fixed penalty: conditional offer by procurator fiscal) or have you previously been subject to an order under section 246(2) or (3) of the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 discharging you absolutely (admonition and absolute discharge)?

questions.title: Have you previously advised the GPhC or the RPSGB of this information?
Question 7
questions.body: Have you previously been included by the Independent Safeguarding Authority (also known as the Independent Barring Board) barred list (in England, Wales or Northern Ireland) or the children’s list or adult’s list maintained by the Scottish Ministers?

questions.title: Have you previously advised the GPhC or the RPSGB of this information?

data.formBody: Before answering any declaration please ensure that you have read and understood published guidance relating to the question.  This is available on our website (relative link provided) and/or included in the guidance for the application for registration, restoration or return to practise.

questionGroups.title: Indemnity Arrangement Declarations
questionGroups.body: Link to Guidance on Web Site.

questions.title: A. Location of Practice
questions.body: I declare that I am applying for registration/restoration/renewal of registration in Part 1/Part 2 of the Register and that, in accordance with Article 20(3) of the Pharmacy Order 2010, I intend to practise as a pharmacist/pharmacy technician in Great Britain, the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.

questions.title: B. Indemnity Arrangements
questions.body: Do you currently have appropriate indemnity arrangements in place?
The indemnity arrangement is provided by:

alternatives.name: P
alternatives.text: A personal arrangement with an indemnity/insurance provider

alternatives.name: C
alternatives.text: A combination of employer provided indemnity arrangement and a personal arrangement.

questions.body: I understand that, upon entry or renewal of entry in the Register, I cannot practise as a pharmacist/pharmacy technician unless there is in force an indemnity arrangement which provides appropriate cover in relation to my scope of practice.

questions.title: C. Changes in Indemnity Arrangements
questions.body: I agree to inform the Registrar in writing within 7 days if I cease to have appropriate indemnity arrangements in force and understand that my entry may be removed from the Register if I no longer have appropriate indemnity arrangements in force.

questionGroups.title: Knowledge of English Language Declaration
questionGroups.body: Link to Guidance on Web Site.

questions.title: D. Evidence of Knowledge of English Language
questions.body: I declare that I have evidence, information or documents which show that I have the knowledge of English which is necessary for the safe and effective practice as a pharmacist/pharmacy technician.

questionGroups.title: Continuing Professional Development Declaration
questionGroups.body: Link to Guidance on Web Site.

questions.title: E. Recording of Continuing Professional Development
questions.body: I declare that I am currently carrying out and recording continuing professional development (CPD) activity, and will continue to do so, in line with the GPhC’s standards and framework for CPD and standards for pharmacy professionals. I will submit my CPD records to the GPhC when I am asked to do so.

questions.title: F. Read and Understood Guidance on Declarations
questions.body: I declare that prior to making my fitness to practise and renewal/registration/restoration declarations, I have read and understood the guidance provided on the GPhC website relating to all these declarations.

questions.title: G. Keeping Details Updated
questions.body: I declare that the information that I have provided in this application for registration/renewal is complete, true and accurate. I am also aware that I am under a duty to notify the Registrar of any changes to my name, home address or other contact details within one month starting on the day on which the change occurred.

questions.title: H. Adherence to the Standards Relating to Conduct, Ethic and Performance
questions.body: With the exception of matters already notified to the General Pharmaceutical Council, I declare that I have and will adhere to the standards relating to conduct, ethic and performance as published by the GPhC.

questions.title: I. Investigations by any Enforcement or Regulatory Body
questions.body: I declare that I am not aware of any investigation by any enforcement or regulatory body, or proceedings brought by such a body that relates to my fitness to practise, that the GPhC is not already aware of, or of any act or omission on my part that might render me liable to an allegation being referred to the Council that my fitness to practise is impaired.

questions.title: J. Duty to Notify Registrar of Changes
questions.body: I declare that I accept that I am under a duty to notify the Registrar if there is any change in the circumstances relating to the fitness to practise declarations that I have made within 7 days starting on the day on which the event occurred.

questions.title: K. Completion of Declarations
questions.body: I declare that I understand if the declaration included in this application for renewal/registration/restoration is not completed to the satisfaction of the Registrar, my application for renewal/registration/restoration will not be processes and I will be deemed to have failed to pay the renewal/registration/restoration fee.

questions.title: L. Integrity of Information Given
questions.body: I declare that I understand that if I am found to have given false or misleading information in connection with my application for registration, restoration or renewal this may be treated as misconduct, which may result in my removal from the Register.

data.formBody: Planned learning – When you decide to develop your knowledge and/or skills in advance of carrying out the learning activity. At least two of the CPD entries that you submit each year must be planned.

questions.title: What are you planning to learn?
questions.body:
Tell us what learning you are planning to carry out. What you need to learn may be new knowledge, skills, or a new attitude or approach – anything that you think will make you better able to do your job as a pharmacy professional or prepare you for a new service or role. You should be as specific as possible.

You should explain why this learning is relevant to you in your role as a pharmacy professional and how it will affect the people using your services. If you don’t think it is relevant or will have a significant beneficial impact on anyone, you might want to consider why you are planning to carry out and record this learning.

Please take care not to disclose any confidential information about patients without their consent.

questions.title: How are you planning to learn it?
questions.body: It is important for you to consider a range of options for achieving your learning across the breadth of your CPD entries. Focus your planned CPD on those activities that are relevant to, or likely to have the biggest impact on, the people using your services.

questions.title: Give an example of how this learning has benefited the people using your services?
questions.body:
Putting learning into practice is a good way to prove that you have actually learnt what you intended. Tell us what specific skills, attitudes and / or behaviours you have gained as a result of your learning.

Include a real example of how the people using your services have benefited from your learning.If you were able to introduce a new service successfully, the benefits will be clear.If you are more confident in your ability to respond to a particular query, or have some new knowledge that you can use in your practice, that is also a beneficial outcome.

Do include any feedback about your practice that you have had from other people.

data.formBody: Unplanned Learning – When you decide to develop your knowledge and/or skills in advance of carrying out the learning activity.

questions.title: Describe an unplanned event or activity that enabled you to learn something new or refresh your knowledge or skills
questions.body:
Tell us about the event or activity. Be specific about the event or activity you describe. If you read an article give it a reference.

Tell us what you learnt from the event or activity in terms of the skills, knowledge, attitudes and/or behaviours you have adopted.

Please take care not to disclose any confidential information about patients without their consent.

questions.title: Give an example of how this learning benefited the people using your services
questions.body:
Include a real example of how the people using your services have benefited from your learning. If you are able to introduce a new service successfully, the benefits will be clear. If you are more confident in your ability to respond to a particular query, or have some new knowledge that you can use in your practice, that is also a beneficial outcome.

Do include any feedback about your practice that you have had from other people.

data.formBody: Peer discussion is a learning and development activity that encourages you to engage with others in your reflection on learning and practice.  You should make sure your peer has agreed to be named in the record of your discussion and is aware that they may be contacted about it.

questions.title: Name of peer
questions.body: (If you took part in a group peer discussion, please only provide details for one person from the group)

questions.title: Peer's role
Name of peer's organisation
Peer's contact number
Peer's contact email
Describe how this peer discussion changed your practice for the benefit of the people using your services.
questions.body:
Tell us why you chose this peer.

Tell us how this peer discussion has helped you to reflect on and make improvements to your practice.

Give a real example of any beneficial outcomes for the people using your services as a result of making changes to your practice.

Do include any feedback about your practice that you have had from other people.

You do not have to include information on the subject(s) discussed if you feel the contents are confidential.

data.formBody: Provide us with a reflective account of how you met one or more of the standards for pharmacy professionals [we will tell you which standard(s) each year].

questions.title:
Tell us briefly about your area of work (the setting of your practice and your main roles).

Tell us briefly who the typical users of your service(s) are. Tell us how you meet the standards for pharmacy professionals we have selected.

Give a real example(s) taken from your practice to illustrate how you meet the standards we have selected.

answers.answer: j dj djg jgjs jdjh dtjh jd

revalidationEntries.title: Ivabradine for use in CT angiography

answers.answer:
The radiologist and interventional cardiologist asked if it was possible to source IV ivabradine for use in CT angiography (CTA) as IV metoprolol (which is what they requested when the service was set up) is not suitable for a number of their patients.  At one of the other centres that the cardiologist works at it is available for routine use.  The consultants were not sure of the dosing protocol.

I performed a quick search and found that it was not licensed in the UK.   I found an article on Science Direct from 2015 which explained why it was used and the benefits to the patient group and outlined the dosing protocol used at a number of European centres.  I explained to the consultants that the medicine is available as an imported unlicensed product and provided them with a copy of the journal article.

The benefit to the patient is that by slowing the heart rate using ivabradine or metoprolol the images that are obtained using CTA are clearer and this results in less radiation exposure to the patient as there is less need to repeat the imaging.

As part of the discussion around the IV ivabradine article it transpired that it would be possible to load the patients orally with the medicine the evening before their procedure and that this would also be possible for the metoprolol patients.  Metoprolol IV would be retained in stock but would only be used if the heart rate was above about 65 to improve the imaging convenience.

As a result of the learning and the consequent discussion my patients who are undergoing CTA are less likely to require administration of IV metoprolol which has reduced their risk of an IV medication error and also reduced the procedure costs and time.

At the start of the year I was involved in facilitating a series of 2 day workshops for pharmacists across the North West, aimed at developing advanced techniques in the assessment and management of urgent cases. The course was for community pharmacists and was co-facilitated by 2 GP's. One of the key skills the workshop aimed to develop is communication skills and better patient centered consultations. The GP's taught the pharmacists how to structure a consultation and how to take a full history.

Although I was there as a facilitator not a delegate I found the sessions really useful and learnt questioning techniques such as "ICE" and "TED" to help make consultations more patient centered.

I have been able to apply this knowledge to my own practice in several ways. As a community pharmacist I have been able to approach my consultations with patients in a different way and have found I was able to find out what the patient really wanted to ask much more effectively, which then made me able to tailor my advice accordingly. I have received some great feedback from patients who have often returned to let me know the outcomes from my advice.

I have also been able to apply this knowledge to my role as CPPE tutor and brought in various aspects of the things I learnt to the various workshops I have delivered. This has really helped to ensure the message about patient-centred care is embedded in the training I deliver.

Finally I have been able to apply this knowledge to my role as an Education supervisor for the general practice pharmacist training pathway. One of the key themes of the pathway is consultation and communication skills and I have been able to help coach the pharmacists to think about ways they can make their consultations more patient centred.

The contents of the conversation will remain confidential.

The discussion centred around communication as part of the Tutela lead for my site and the issues involved with co-ordinating the site response with the remote project manager's response.  Communication had become difficult and workloads had been arranged around the original go-live date - this had slipped without explanation or discussion.

My concerns during the discussion related to managing the workload so that it did not impact on patient care and helping the project manager understand the limitations that we were working to.

Ultimately we managed to work out a method whereby the PM compromised and started to understand the pressures locally.  The project was implemented relatively smoothly although the final sign off from site did not occur before the site went live.  This meant that not all of the processes were signed off and not all of the training was completed.

From the perspective of the service users (nursing staff), despite the miscommunication from the project manager, the site managed the initial go-live problems and  no impact on patient care was noted.  From the patient's perspective they were not aware that there had been any process change at the site.

I am planning to learn about the use of indigo carmine in endoscopy.

Previously our endoscopists made up a solution in theatres using gelofusine, adrenaline and methylene blue for visualising lesions.  I was never sure what they were doing or why so had not queried it. 

They now want to change to either a pre-mixed syringe or a box with all the equipment and instructions in it and want to change the dye to indigo carmine so I need to understand what this does and why it is used.

I will talk with the endoscopy lead practitioner to find out more of the practicalities about it.  I have seen this on the UKCPA website so I will look at the forums to find out how it is used in other sites if that is being shared. 

I will also perform a quick literature search to see what I can find out about the use of dyes in endoscopy.

With respect to sourcing the product I will look at Itemmaster and find the code which will give me the supplier.  It is likely to be an unlicensed product or an unlicensed use so I will use the evidence from the literature search to support the application for approval of use to the MAC.

I will also talk to other pharmacy managers who are using the product in their hospitals to find out how they are managing it there.

From Itemmaster I found out that it is an unlicensed product sourced through Mawdsley's.  We are therefore able to get it relatively easily for our consultants.

From the literature search I found out that it is not taken up by mucosal cells in the same way as methylene blue and has a wider range of applications than methylene blue so it is probably more effective and safer for patients.

From the UKCPA forums I found out that there are pre-mixed syinges available of gelofusine and indigo carmine but that these cannot have the adrenaline added because the pH difference between adrenaline and gelofusine would result in incompatibility.  Additionally other sites use 1:1000 adrenaline and dilute this further.   I discussed this with the endoscopy lead practitioner (an RN) and we agreed that the most appropriate course of action would be to use 1:10000 adrenaline and indigo carmine and put these in a marked box together with the instructions and equipment for drawing up and mixing.  The gelofusine needs to be warmed so cannot be included in the box.  This reduces the risk to the staff of making an error and increases the benefit to the patient as indigo carmine allows dysplastic lesions to be visualised more easily under endoscopy.

I have been asked to pilot a full day Care Homes Study day for pharmacists on September 8th.

I need to be able to confidently deliver the day and therefore need a good understanding of the subject as well as knowledge of the key legislation governing care homes. The focus is also on medicines optimisation so I want to gain knowledge on the different tools available to support medicines optimisation and the pro's and cons of each.

his learning has benefited the pharmacists that attended the study day because I was able to confidently lead the day and deliver the presentations. I was also able to facilitate activities involving the medicines optimisation tools such as STOP-START, NOTEARS, and 7 steps.

The delegates asked lots of questions which I was able to either answer or signpost them to the appropriate place.

I was able to provide practical tips for how to implement strategies to manage poor practice and increase resilience of care homes. This included looking at issues regarding residents, team working and regulation.

I was also able to advise on the mental capacity act and related NICE quality standards and advise on good practice when dealing with patients with dementia.

After the workshop I gave out evaluation forms to all delegates which asked them to comment on the content of the day as well as my skills as a facilitator. I was pleased to read that all delegates enjoyed the day, but more importantly had identified areas of their practice that they intended to change as a result of the workshop. I feel that my initial learning will also benefit residents in care homes because of the information I have passed on to the delegates.

I plan to read all of the workshop materials and facilitators guides to gain a thorough understanding of what is covered in the workshop and complete the recommended reading that is included.

I am aware that the CPPE polypharmacy distance learning package looks at medicines optimisation and the various tools available so I intend to complete that package prior to running the workshop.

One of the pre-workshop tasks for the workshop is to complete the CPPE care homes e-learning program so I intend to complete that as well to ensure I understand the basics and have an understanding of the background knowledge people will bring to the workshop.
I need to fully understand holistic assessment and models of delivery for NVQ in the pharmacy setting.

I am going to attend a training day which will cover the following:

  • An over view of holistic assessment
  • How to identify opportunities for holistic assessment
  • How to maximise oppotunities generated by existing learning activities
  • Identify commonality in local training and competency assessments

As lead assessor on my trust I need to be fully up to date with current practices regarding NVQ.  I have been able to pass all my learning on to my assessors which helps them to assessor holistically and support their candidates to achieve the best they can while undertaking their qualification.  This will in turn lead to well qualified staff to deliver a high quality service to both our patients and service users.

I attended the CPPE national meeting in October and there was a session on case based discussions and workplace based assessments.

I learnt about the differences between formative and summative assessments and when each would be used.

I learnt about the different types of workplace based assessments and how they support Millers pyramid as a means of assessing clinical competence.

I learnt about the strength and weaknesses of workplace based assessments and how they can be used.

I also took part in a session on case based discussions and used the RPS proforma as a guide. I presented a case to one of my peers and received really useful feedback and then swapped roles and listened to my colleague present their case and offered feedback. I found the process really useful and now feel confident that I can explain and demonstrate the process to others.

As part of my role as education supervisor for the general practice pharmacist training pathway I will be involved in workplace based assessments.

I feel this session equipped me with the knowledge I need to be able to both undertake a case based discussion as tutor, and to be able to explain the process to others so that they can support each other as peers using case based discussions.

This will enable the pharmacists on the pathway to develop critical reflective skills as well as the ability to give and receive constructive feedback. This should lead to improved clinical practice which will result in a better experience for the patients.
sethsth sth srh sryh sryj sryh rsy

questions.question: What is myGPhC?
questions.answer: myGPhC is a password-protected, self-service website for registrants of the General Pharmaceutical Council.

questions.question: Will I be charged for using this website?
questions.answer: No.

questions.question: What does this website offer?
questions.answer:
You can use myGPhC to:

  • renew your registration
  • update your personal details
  • view or download receipts.

questions.question: Where can I get support to use this site?
questions.answer: Please contact the GPhC Customer Contact Centre if you have any issues or would like help. You can phone 020 3713 8000 or email info@pharmacyregulation.org

questions.question: What web browsers will this site work with?
questions.answer:
For your security and to get the best from the site, we encourage you to keep your web browser updated to the latest version. We have tested the site with all recent (as at January 2014) versions of the most popular browsers and some older versions of Firefox, Opera and Internet Explorer (version 6 onwards). We offer support to users of all these browsers.

We don't support mobile devices including ones using iOS (Apple devices such as iPad and iPhone), Windows Phone, BlackBerry and Android.

categories.name: Signing in and using your password

questions.question: How do I sign in?
questions.answer: Go to our sign-in page at https://myGPhC.org/account/signin.aspx. There are two ways you can sign in to myGPhC. You can use your GPhC registration number and your myGPhC password, or your GPhC registration number and the renewal number you get with your renewal notice.

questions.question: Do I need to set up a password?
questions.answer: No, your new registration number and renewal number will allow you to access myGPhC, and you can continue to sign in using the renewal number printed in your renewal notice each year. However, we suggest you set up a confidential password for future use.

questions.question: How can I set up a new password?
questions.answer:
If you don't have a myGPhC password you will need to sign in using your GPhC registration number and the renewal number you get with your renewal notice. Once you have signed in you can create a myGPhC password to use when signing in instead.

Step 1: Sign in to myGPhC using your registration number and renewal number. These numbers are on your renewal notice in the section 'Renewing your registration as a pharmacist/pharmacy technician'.

Step 2: On the Welcome page there is a tab headed 'Registration'. Under that tab click on the 'Create password' button which will take you to a page headed 'Create or change password'.

Step 3: Following the instructions about the correct makeup of the password, enter your new password in the 'New password' box, and then confirm this by repeating the password in the 'Confirm password' box. Click on the 'Submit' button. If your new password has been accepted a message will appear saying you have successfully created your password.

Step 4: If you need to renew your registration, continue to Registration renewal

questions.question: I cannot remember my password, or whether I have set up a password for myGPhC.
questions.answer:
You can use your renewal notice number instead of a password to sign in, and then create a new password.

See How can I set up a new password?

You can also click on the Forgotten your password? link on the myGPhC Sign-in page to reset your password, using other details we hold about you.

questions.question: I am told that my password is incorrect and I cannot sign in.
questions.answer:
If you have set up a password and have forgotten it you can use your renewal notice number instead of a password to sign in.

See How can I set up a new password?

You can also click on the Forgotten your password? link on the myGPhC Sign-in page to reset your password, using other details we hold about you.

questions.question: How do I renew?
questions.answer:
Step 1: Make sure that you have your renewal notice with you. If your renewal notice says that you are to pay by credit or debit card but you want to pay using Direct Debit, you will need to set up a Direct Debit before making your declarations. Download the correct Direct Debit form from http://www.pharmacyregulation.org/faqs/registration/renewal-forms

Please fill in and sign the correct form, using your registration number as the reference number. Send the form to:

Customer Service Team
General Pharmaceutical Council
25 Canada Square
London
E14 5LQ


We must get this new Direct Debit form by the date given in Step 4 of your renewal notice (see 'Pay the fee').

We will send you a payment schedule and a notice that your Direct Debit has been set up. The notice will also give you a new deadline by which you must make your renewal declarations. If you do not complete your declarations in time the Direct Debit will not be collected and you will need to make your online renewal declarations and payment using a debit or credit card.

If you are setting up a quarterly Direct Debit there will be a yearly administration fee of £15 which will be taken with the first payment each year.

Step 2 (a): If you are paying by credit or debit card please have your card with you. You will be transferred to the online secure payment system after you have completed your declarations.

Step 2 (b): If you already have a yearly or quarterly Direct Debit set up to pay your renewal fee, all you will need to do is complete your renewal declarations.

Step 3: Sign in to myGPhC. See How do I sign in?

Step 4: Fill in and confirm the declarations. Once you have confirmed these you will be transferred to the online payment system if you are paying by credit or debit card. If you already have a Direct Debit set up then the process will be complete.

Step 5: Once your credit or debit card payment has been made you will be transferred back to myGPhC and the process is complete. If you entered an email address you will get a confirmation email for your payment. This is not a receipt. You will be able to download a receipt from myGPhC after completing your online renewal if you have paid by debit or credit card.

questions.question: How do I get a receipt for my renewal fee payment?
questions.answer:
Select the 'Receipts' option from the Renewal tab to visit the Receipts page and download or view your receipts.

Payment methodWhen the receipt is available
Online24 hours after payment
Phone24 hours after payment
Direct Debit14 days after payment

If you are paying by quarterly Direct Debit, each time a payment is taken the amount paid and amount still owing will be updated on your receipt.

questions.question: How can I pay my renewal fee online?
questions.answer: After signing in, select the 'Registration renewal' option from the Renewal tab to go to the Registration renewal page and follow the instructions there. You will be guided through the declaration and payment process.

questions.question: When can I pay my renewal fee online?
questions.answer: We will post your renewal notice to you. This tells you when your renewal fee is due. Once we have sent out your notice, you can pay your renewal fee online.

questions.question: What is the extra password step I encountered when making my online payment?
questions.answer: Depending on the type of card you use, you may be asked to enter a password before you can finish making your payment. This is a security system called 3-D Secure. It was introduced recently so that the card-issuing bank can be more sure that it's the real card owner making the payment, so reducing the chances of fraudulent card use. If your bank uses 3-D Secure and you haven't got a password yet you may be asked to set one up. For information on 3-D Secure, please go to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3-D_Secure

questions.question: What is 3-D Secure?
questions.answer:
3-D Secure is a password-based security system used to reduce the risks of fraudulent card use. Before the payment can be completed, the user is redirected to a webpage owned by the card-issuing bank. At this point the card holder has to enter a password.

For information on 3-D Secure, please go to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3-D_Secure

questions.question: What are 'Verified by Visa', 'MasterCard SecureCode', 'J/Secure'?
questions.answer:
Depending on the type of card you use, you may be asked to enter a password before you can finish making your payment. This is a security system called 3-D Secure. It was introduced recently so that the card-issuing bank can be more sure that it's the real card owner making the payment, so reducing the chances of fraudulent card use.

Each issuing bank has its own name for their own particular version of 3-D Secure. Some of the most common are:

Card issuer3-D Secure version name
Visa

Verified by Visa

MasterCardMasterCard SecureCode
JCB InternationalJ/Secure

For information on 3-D Secure, please go to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3-D_Secure

questions.question: Why can't I use my web browser's Back button or History feature when I am paying my renewal fee?
questions.answer: There are a number of steps you have to go through when you are making your declarations and paying your renewal fee. You have to do these in the right order, one after the other. Using the web browser's Back button or History feature can interrupt the order of these steps. If you use the Back button or History feature, you will be redirected to the start of the process and you will need to start again. You also have to finish each step of the process satisfactorily, or the process is abandoned.

questions.question: I want to change from credit or debit card to yearly or quarterly Direct Debit. How do I do this?
questions.answer:
You need to set up your Direct Debit first. So do not make your declarations until you have done this, because your declarations cannot be recorded without a completed payment. Please download the correct Direct Debit form by going to http://www.pharmacyregulation.org/faqs/registration/renewal-forms

Please fill in and sign the correct form, using your registration number as the reference number. Send the form to:00

Customer Service Team
General Pharmaceutical Council
25 Canada Square
London
E14 5LQ


We must get this new Direct Debit form by the date given in Step 4 of your renewal notice (see 'Pay the fee').

We will send you a payment schedule and a notice that your Direct Debit has been set up. The notice will also give you a new deadline by which you must make your renewal declarations. If you do not complete your declarations in time the Direct Debit will not be collected and you will need to make your online renewal declarations and payment using a debit or credit card.

If you are setting up a quarterly Direct Debit there will be a yearly administration fee of £15, which will be taken with the first payment each year.

questions.question: I want to change from yearly or quarterly Direct Debit to paying by credit or debit card. How do I do this?
questions.answer:
You need to do this before you make your declarations. While you still have a Direct Debit do not make your declarations as you will not be directed to the online payment page. You will need to email us at info@pharmacyregulation.org, quoting your GPhC registration number and asking us to cancel your Direct Debit. You will get a notice from us saying that this has been done. The notice will also give you a new deadline by which you must make your renewal declarations and payment. You will then need to sign in to myGPhC before that date to complete your declarations and make your payment by either credit or debit card.

We advise you to contact your bank or building society to cancel the Direct Debit instruction they hold.

questions.question: How do I change my Direct Debit payment from quarterly to yearly (or vice versa)?
questions.answer:
Please email us at info@pharmacyregulation.org, quoting your GPhC registration number. Please make sure you tell us before the date given in Step 4 of your renewal notice (see 'Pay the fee'). You can make your declarations any time before the date given on your renewal notice in the section 'Renewing your registration as a pharmacist/pharmacy technician'.

If you are changing to a quarterly Direct Debit we will charge a yearly administration fee of £15, which will be added to your first payment each year.

data.formBody: Have the proof ready prior to filling out this form since you will not be able to amend this form after submitting it.

questions.title: Will you be able to submit a full set of revalidation records within an extended time period?
How long would you like to extend the submission deadline? (Max 9 months from renewal date)
Describe the extenuating circumstance.
How many CPDs in total will you be able to complete? (0-4)
How many of those will be Unplanned CPDs? (0-2)
Describe the extenuating circumstance.
Will you be able to complete the Peer Discussion?
Will you be able to complete the reflective account?
